content:
Introduction

Androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS) is a rare, X-linked recessive disorder of sex development caused by defective androgen receptors.  Patients with complete AIS have a 46,XY genotype yet have a female phenotype (ie, female external genitalia, breast development) despite the presence of testes and male-range androgen production (

figure 1
).

Pathogenesis



Testosterone and dihydrotestosterone (DHT) normally interact with androgen receptors in target tissues to induce androgenic effects (ie, virilization).



AIS, an X-linked recessive disorder, is caused by loss-of-function mutations in the androgen receptor gene on the X chromosome.  These mutations lead to a lack of response to androgens, resulting in abnormal sexual development (ie, undervirilization) beginning in utero:

Development of internal genitalia



  • 46,XY patients with AIS have an intact SRY gene on the Y chromosome, which induces the embryonic gonadal ridges to differentiate into testes (
    figure 2
    ).  In the testes, Sertoli cells produce anti-mÃ¼llerian hormone (AMH) and Leydig cells produce testosterone.
  • AMH causes regression of the mÃ¼llerian structures; therefore, patients with AIS do not develop female internal genitalia (eg, uterus, cervix, upper third of the vagina).
  • However, because testosterone cannot bind to the nonfunctioning androgen receptors within wolffian ducts, internal male genitalia (eg, vas deferens, seminal vesicles, epididymis) are absent.

Development of external genitalia



  • Testosterone is converted into DHT by the enzyme 5-alpha reductase.  Normally, DHT stimulates testicular descent and induces embryonic structures (eg, genital tubercle (
    figure 3
    )) to differentiate into male external genitalia (eg, penis).
  • Patients with AIS have no response to DHT because of their defective androgen receptors.  As a result, male external genitalia do not develop and the testes remain undescended (cryptorchid).  In the absence of DHT activity, female external genitalia (eg, lower two-thirds of the vagina, vulva) develop.


Testosterone is not overtly elevated because it is peripherally aromatized to estrogen. 



At puberty, the testes increase production of testosterone to male-range levels, causing increased estrogen production through aromatization.  Therefore, patients with AIS undergo breast development because of the combination of androgen resistance (testosterone suppresses breast development) and high levels of estrogen.  Peripheral androgen resistance also results in minimal or absent axillary and pubic hair.  Menses are absent due to the absence of female internal genitalia (ie, uterus).  The testes remain cryptorchid with impaired spermatogenesis.

Clinical presentation



Classically, complete AIS presents during adolescence with a female phenotype and the following features:



  • Primary amenorrhea (ie, absence of menarche by age 15 in girls with secondary sexual characteristics [eg, breast development])


Examination typically shows:



  • Minimal or absent axillary and pubic hair
  • Normal breast development (eg, sexual maturity [Tanner] stage 4)
  • Normal female external genitalia (eg, vulva)
  • A short, blind vaginal pouch
  • Usually, intraabdominal testes that are occasionally palpable in the inguinal canal or labia majora
  • Tall stature


However, depending on the degree of impaired androgen receptor function, AIS can produce a range of phenotypes of varying levels of undervirilization.  These range from classic complete AIS, partial AIS (mostly female phenotype with mild pubertal virilization [eg, clitoromegaly]), and mild AIS (eg, predominantly male phenotype but impaired spermatogenesis and gynecomastia).

Diagnosis



The diagnosis may be delayed until after puberty (when a patient is evaluated for primary amenorrhea) because patients with complete AIS have female external genitalia at birth and normal breast development at puberty.



Primary amenorrhea evaluation includes history (particularly pubertal development), physical examination, hormonal evaluation, and imaging (internal reproductive organ assessment).  AIS is suspected with the following features:



  • Female phenotype (ie, female external genitalia)
  • Abnormal female pubertal development:
    • Adrenarche:  minimal or absent axillary and pubic hair
    • Thelarche:  normal breast development
    • Menarche:  absent menses
  • A blind vaginal pouch
  • Absent uterus on pelvic ultrasonography
  • Elevated (ie, male-range) testosterone levels


Karyotyping (ie, 46,XY) and/or sequencing of the androgen receptor gene confirms the diagnosis.

Differential diagnosis



The differential diagnosis for AIS includes other differences of sex development that present with a female phenotype, primary amenorrhea, and abnormal pubertal development (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 1
); these features usually indicate a genetic or anatomic abnormality:



  • MÃ¼llerian agenesis (ie, Mayer-Rokitansky-KÃ¼ster-Hauser syndrome or congenital absence of the vagina [46,XX]):  presents with female external genitalia, primary amenorrhea, a blind vaginal pouch, and absent or rudimentary uterus.  The ovaries are normal and functioning, therefore, patients have breast development.  However, testosterone levels are in the normal female range, and axillary/pubic hair is present.
  • Female gonadal dysgenesis (eg, Turner syndrome [45,X]):  presents with female external genitalia and primary amenorrhea; however, patients have female internal genitalia (uterus, fallopian tubes), streak ovaries, minimal breast development (due to deficient estrogen production), and normal axillary/pubic hair.
  • 5-Alpha-reductase deficiency (46,XY):  presents with ambiguous (undervirilized) or female external genitalia at birth because DHT (the hormone required for differentiation of male external genitalia) is absent during embryogenesis; however, male internal genitalia are present due to testosterone-induced wolffian duct development.  At puberty, testosterone reaches male-range levels, causing marked virilization (eg, clitoromegaly).  Patients do not develop breasts because androgen receptors are functional, which allows testosterone to inhibit breast development and prevents peripheral aromatization into estrogen.  Axillary and pubic hair are present due to functioning androgen receptors.
  • Complete male gonadal dysgenesis (ie, Swyer syndrome [46,XY]):  presents with female external genitalia and primary amenorrhea.  However, the mÃ¼llerian structures (eg, uterus, fallopian tubes, vagina) are intact due to abnormal testes development and the subsequent lack of AMH and testosterone during embryogenesis.  Testosterone is low and axillary and pubic hairs are minimal.

Management



Management options are individualized for each patient and typically include:



  • Psychosocial support for the patient and family
  • Maintenance of sexual function
    • Estrogen replacement therapy to induce and maintain female secondary sexual characteristics
    • Dilator therapy of the vagina or vaginal surgery to improve sexual function in adulthood
  • Management of cryptorchid testes
    • MRI may be required to locate the testes.
    • Prophylactic gonadectomy may be considered after puberty to reduce the risk for testicular cancer associated with AIS (eg, cryptorchid testes).

Prognosis



The long-term prognosis for complete AIS is typically good, although fertility options are limited due to impaired spermatogenesis.

Summary



Androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS) (46,XY) (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 2
) is a rare, X-linked recessive disorder of sexual development caused by androgen receptor dysfunction.  Complete AIS presents with female external genitalia and normal breast development.  The diagnosis is often made when patients experience primary amenorrhea following puberty.  Evaluation typically shows minimal axillary and pubic hair, a blind vaginal pouch, absence of the uterus, elevated (ie, male-range) testosterone levels, and cryptorchid testes.  Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis.
